 For ease of experiments, in Sec.4.1 we have used a lower resolution, 64\times64, a light ResNet-18 model, and a modern rapid training scheduler. On the other hand in this section we reproduce the results of the original paper (Li et al.)[ref]26 using a VGG-16 model and 224\times224 input size and then carry out our LP analysis further confirming our observations.
We take the setting of[ref]26, which considers the ImageNet[ref]42 transfer to various datasets, in particular CUB, and Scenes. We use the same model architecture (VGG-16) and training procedures described in [ref]26, which proposes LwF, closely reproducing their ImageNet \to Scenes as the first step in the sequence (see Tab.6). We also include an EWC baseline under two conditions: (a) large 位\lambda value (位=8k8\lambda=8k), so the network is inclined to preserve the knowledge important to the previous tasks, and (b) small 位\lambda value (位=0.5k0.5\lambda=0.5k), so the network is encouraged to perform competitively on the current task. The results are shown in Figure8 and Table8. We first note that our results for the first task switch are consistent with those reported in[ref]26 (seeTab.6). Fig.8 reveals that although the forgetting in terms of the traditional measure is high for finetuning compared to LwF (as shown in[ref]26), the LP accuracy of these methods suggest a much less drastic forgetting. Furthermore, the LP performance across finetuning and other methods is not as drastically different as their respective observed accuracies are. Indeed, we observe that on the third task, finetuning outperforms LwF in representation forgetting on ImageNet.
Similarly EWC does not clearly outperform naive finetuning. For example, if using one hyper-parameter for the regularization term the performance closely tracks finetuning. On the other hand using 位=8k8\lambda=8k we observe the best LP performance on ImageNet through the task sequence but degraded current task performance as seen inFig.8. Although we followed the training procedure as closely as possible to the ones reported by[ref]26, the results are slightly different from the ones reported in[ref]26 due to (a) not using the task-head warm-up step, where the backbone network is first frozen and the newly added task head is trained until convergence (warm-up), and then the entire network is trained until convergence, and (b) stochasticity of training neural networks.
